chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with suspected sepsis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
If a person with any infection presents with suspected sepsis, arrange urgent assessment to identify markers of increased risk of severe illness or death, and manage appropriately.

  • Ask the person/carers about:
    • Any recent fever or rigors.
    • Any symptoms suggesting specific infection, such as dysuria or productive cough.
    • Clinical features suggesting dehydration, such as reduced urine output in the past 18 hours.
    • Any altered behaviour, mental state, or cognition, such as not responding normally to social cues or waking only with prolonged stimulation, or new irritability (in children); new-onset confusion (in adults). See the CKS topic on Delirium for more information.
    • Any sudden change or deterioration in functional ability.
    • Possible risk factors for sepsis, including co-morbidities and drug treatments.
    • Possible risk factors for antibiotic resistance, such as recent or previous antibiotic therapy, previous hospital admissions, and residency in a care home, for example.
    • Immunization status (particularly in infants and young children).
  • Examine the person to assess for:
    • General appearance, level of consciousness and cognition.
      • Cognitive assessment should include recognition of new-onset confusion, disorientation, and/or agitation. See the CKS topic on Delirium for detailed information on performing a cognitive assessment.
    • Temperature.
      • Fever is the most common presentation of sepsis. Do not use temperature as the sole predictor of sepsis, however, and do not rely on fever or hypothermia to rule sepsis in or out. See the CKS topics on Feverish children - risk assessment and Feverish children - management for more information on assessment.
    • Heart rate, respiratory rate and signs of respiratory distress, and blood pressure.
      • Signs of respiratory distress include nasal flaring, grunting, and apnoea in children less than 5 years of age.
      • Measure blood pressure in children under 12 years of age and oxygen saturation at any age in community settings, if facilities including a correctly-sized cuff or pulse oximeter are available, and taking a measurement does not cause a delay in assessment or treatment.
      • Hypotension is a presenting feature in 40% of people with sepsis, but be aware that a normal blood pressure does not exclude sepsis in children and young people.
    • Capillary refill time and oxygen saturation (abnormal results may indicate poor peripheral perfusion).
    • Mottled or ashen skin; pallor or cyanosis of the skin, lips or tongue; cold peripheries.
    • A non-blanching rash which may suggest meningococcal disease. See the CKS topic on Meningitis - bacterial meningitis and meningococcal disease for more information on assessment and emergency management.
    • Weak high-pitched or continuous cry (in children under 5 years of age).
    • Any breach of skin integrity (for example cuts, burns, or skin infections) or other skin signs suggesting infection, such as erythema, swelling or discharge at a surgical site, or wound breakdown. See the CKS topics on Burns and scalds and Cellulitis - acute for more information.
    • Dry mucous membranes or other signs of dehydration. See the CKS topic on Feverish children - risk assessment for more information on assessment.
    • The possible underlying source of infection.
  • Use a sepsis risk stratification tool to assess the risk of clinical deterioration including severe illness or death from sepsis, depending on the person's age, risk factors, and clinical features of concern. Possible tools include:
    • Royal College of Physicians National Early Warning Score (NEWS) 2 for non-pregnant adults.
    • NICE risk stratification tool for children under 5 years or UK Sepsis Trust GP Paediatric Sepsis decision support tool for children under 5 years. 
    • NICE risk stratification tool for children aged 5–11 years or UK Sepsis Trust GP Paediatric Sepsis decision support tool for children aged 5–11 years.
    • NICE risk stratification tool for adults, children and young people aged 12 years and over or UK Sepsis Trust GP Sepsis decision support tool for non-pregnant adults and young people aged 12 years and over.
    • UK Sepsis Trust GP Maternal Sepsis decision support tool for women who are pregnant or up to 6 weeks postpartum.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on how to assess a person with suspected infection and sepsis are largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Sepsis: recognition, diagnosis and early management [NICE, 2019], the international consensus report Surviving Sepsis Campaign (SSC): International Guidelines for Management of Sepsis and Septic Shock: 2016 [Rhodes, 2017], a consensus document published by a Task Force of the Society of Critical Care Medicine and the European Society of Intensive Care Medicine The Third International Consensus Definitions for Sepsis and Septic Shock (Sepsis-3) [Singer, 2016], the UK Sepsis Trust Sepsis Manual [Daniels, 2017], a Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) publication Sepsis: guidance for GPs [RCGP, 2018], the Royal College of Physicians (RCP) working party report National Early Warning Score (NEWS) 2. Standardising the assessment of acute-illness severity in the NHS [RCP, 2017], and expert opinion in review articles on sepsis [Gauer, 2013; Plunkett, 2015; Freitag, 2016; Gotts, 2016; Keeley, 2017; Cecconi, 2018; Fleischmann-Struzek, 2018].

Assessing clinical features on history-taking

  • Overall, the NICE clinical guideline evidence review on the use of physiological symptoms and signs to identify whether sepsis is present found very low-quality evidence with significant heterogeneity between studies regarding study populations, settings, thresholds and methods of analysis. The lack of consistency between results and inability to perform a meta-analysis resulted in the guideline development group using consensus opinion and other literature to guide recommendations [NICE, 2019]. 
  • The recommendation to ask about symptoms suggesting specific infection is based on expert opinion in an international consensus document, as this may help to identify the source of infection and the likely infecting pathogen [Singer, 2016].
  • The recommendation to assess for reduced urine output and clinical features of dehydration is based on the fact that people with sepsis are at high risk of acute kidney injury (AKI), and oliguria or anuria may indicate tissue hypoperfusion [Gauer, 2013; NICE, 2019].
  • The NICE clinical guideline notes that changes in behaviour and/or mental state are a strong risk factor for mortality from sepsis, based on very low-quality evidence from observational studies, and the experience and opinion of the NICE guideline development group [NICE, 2019]. This is supported by expert opinion in a review article, which notes that behaviour changes such as agitation may be the only clinical feature of sepsis in older people [Gauer, 2013].
  • The NICE clinical guideline notes that changes in cognitive function in older people may present as acute changes in functional abilities [NICE, 2019].
  • The NICE clinical guideline states there should be a high index of suspicion of sepsis if a person has additional risk factors for sepsis [NICE, 2019]. This is supported by expert opinion in a review article [Gauer, 2013].
  • The recommendation to check for risk factors for antibiotic resistance is based on the SSC international consensus report [Rhodes, 2017] and expert opinion in a review article [Keeley, 2017].
  • The recommendation to ask about immunization status is extrapolated from expert opinion in a review article [Plunkett, 2015].

Assessing clinical features on examination

  • The RCGP publication notes that respiratory rate, blood pressure/perfusion, and cognition are the three physiological elements most predictive of sepsis [RCGP, 2018].
  • The recommendation on performing a cognitive assessment is based on the RCP report on the NEWS 2 tool [RCP, 2017], and is supported by the expert opinion of an external reviewer of this CKS topic.
  • The recommendation not to use temperature as the sole predictor of sepsis is based on the NICE clinical guideline, which notes that some people with sepsis are less likely to present with fever, including the elderly, frail, very ill, people who are immunosuppressed (for example taking anticancer treatment), and young infants or children. This was based on very low-quality evidence from observational studies and the experience and opinion of the guideline development group [NICE, 2019].
    • A rise in temperature may be a normal physiological response in people following surgery or trauma [NICE, 2019]. It may also, however, help in the diagnosis of underlying infection [Singer, 2016].
  • The NICE clinical guideline notes that tachycardia is associated with a poorer prognosis and increased risk of morbidity and mortality from sepsis, based on very low-quality evidence from observational studies and the experience and opinion of the NICE guideline development group [NICE, 2019].
    • It also notes that older people with infection may not develop tachycardia, and may develop a new arrhythmia instead.
  • The recommendation to assess for increased respiratory rate and signs of respiratory distress is based on the fact that they are associated with a poorer prognosis, and pneumonia is a common cause of sepsis [NICE, 2019].
  • The recommendations on measuring blood pressure and oxygen saturation in community settings is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2019].
    • NICE notes that extremes of blood pressure are a cause of clinical concern, but should always be interpreted in the context of previous recorded blood pressure readings, if possible.
    • In addition, expert opinion in a review article notes that normal blood pressure does not exclude a diagnosis of sepsis, as organ perfusion can be impaired in the context of normal blood pressure [Cecconi, 2018]. This is supported by expert opinion in an additional review article, which notes that children often maintain blood pressure even in late stages of septic shock [Plunkett, 2015].
    • The information that hypotension is a presenting feature in 40% of people with sepsis is based on expert opinion in a review article [Gauer, 2013].
  • The information about a delayed capillary refill time is based on expert opinion in an international consensus document [Singer, 2016].
  • The recommendation to check for skin colour changes, signs of cyanosis, or a non-blanching rash are based on the fact these indicate a high risk of severe illness or death from sepsis [NICE, 2019].

Using a sepsis risk stratification tool to assess risk of serious illness and deterioration

  • The recommendation to use a structured risk stratification tool is largely based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2019], the RCP working party report [RCP, 2017], the UK Sepsis Trust publication [Daniels, 2017], and expert opinion in a review article [Freitag, 2016].
    • These tools are designed to identify people at highest risk of morbidity and mortality from sepsis who need immediate potentially life-saving hospital treatment.
    • The RCP National Early Warning Score (NEWS) 2 tool is recommended in the RCP report as it has now been validated in many settings within the NHS and internationally, including emergency departments and pre-hospital settings (including use by paramedic crews). More specifically, it has been shown to be a strong indicator of increased risk of serious clinical deterioration and mortality in people with sepsis [RCP, 2017]. The NICE guideline development group state that the NEWS could be implementable in primary care, but note the lack of validation studies in this setting [NICE, 2019], and the RCGP publication also states that the NEWS 2 can be considered as part of the assessment of a person with suspected sepsis [RCGP, 2018]. The use of the NEWS 2 tool in primary care is also supported by the expert opinion of two external reviewers of this CKS topic.
    • The NICE clinical guideline based their recommendations on low-quality evidence with low specificity and sensitivity, and the experience and opinion of the NICE guideline development group [NICE, 2019]. An expert reviewer of this CKS topic notes that the NICE recommendations on risk stratification tools used data with poor predictive values which were not derived from primary care, and which may have limited applicability in this setting.
    • CKS notes that there are subtle differences between the classification of risk categories and management pathways of the UK Sepsis Trust publication and the NICE clinical guideline. The UK Sepsis Trust acknowledges these differences and suggests either risk assessment approach can be used [Daniels, 2017].
  • CKS notes that the Sepsis-3 Task Force has developed an additional risk stratification tool (the 'quick Sequential [Sepsis-related] Organ Failure Assessment [SOFA]' or 'qSOFA' clinical score) to identify adults with suspected sepsis who are at increased risk of significant morbidity and mortality from organ dysfunction. A retrospective analysis mainly US-derived hospital data identified increased respiratory rate, altered mental state, and low systolic blood pressure as markers for people at increased risk of clinical deterioration and mortality. The Task Force noted that it uses readily measurable identifiers, does not need laboratory tests, and can be assessed quickly and repeatedly [Singer, 2016].
    • The NICE clinical guideline evidence review of different risk assessment tools including qSOFA found insufficient evidence that one scoring tool performs better than another, and concluded that qSOFA needs further validation in clinical practice [NICE, 2019].
    • Several additional commentators note that the qSOFA score needs further prospective validation in diverse clinical settings, and it may have reduced applicability as a stand-alone screening tool in the UK due to various limitations [Gotts, 2016; Daniels, 2017]. Furthermore, it is not validated for use in children [Fleischmann-Struzek, 2018]. As a result, CKS has not currently recommended this tool for use in UK community settings.
